    • Field Detail

      • pfcManager

        private final PfcManager pfcManager

      • finder

        public org.xguzm.pathfinding.grid.finders.ThetaStarGridFinder<org.xguzm.pathfinding.grid.GridCell> finder
        The finder itself.

        Per documentation in the PathfinderCore library, a ThetaStarGridFinder is defined rather simply. First, it's worth noting that it's based on the much more general ThetaStarFinder. Secondly, a theta star finder is just defined as: A finder which will use theta star algorithm on a grid (any angle path finding). It also lets you find a path based on coordinates rather than nodes. A ThetaStarGridFinder is thus defined as... 

         A helper class to which lets you find a path based on coordinates rather than nodes
 on an instance of NavigationGridGraph

    • Constructor Detail

      • PfcFinder

        public PfcFinder​(PfcManager pfcManager)
        Create a new instance of the finder by using options provided in the PfcFinderOptions class.

    • Method Detail

      • getCellPath

        public java.util.ArrayList<org.xguzm.pathfinding.grid.GridCell> getCellPath​(Coordinate<java.lang.Double> startDouble,
                                                                            Coordinate<java.lang.Double> endDouble)
        Get a path that's notated in PathfindingCore's default GridCell implementation.

        Meccanum robots (or at least those that use this library) don't actually read GridCells - rather, they read coordinates. Although this is a public function, it's rather unlikely you'll ever need to use it. Rather, you should go check out getCoordinatePath(Coordinate, Coordinate).

        Parameters:
        startDouble - the start position (notated as a double coordinate).
        endDouble - the end position (notated as a double coordinate).
        Returns:
        a list of scaled-up (1440x1440) GridCell instances.

      • getCoordinatePath

        public java.util.ArrayList<Coordinate<java.lang.Double>> getCoordinatePath​(Coordinate<java.lang.Double> start,
                                                                           Coordinate<java.lang.Double> end)
        Get a path, from a start coordinate to an end coordinate, that's directly readable by our implementation of the pathfinding system.
        Parameters:
        start - the start coordinate.
        end - the end coordinate.
        Returns:
        a group, composed of individual Coordinate items.
